column1: Frankfort is the capital city of the Commonwealth of Kentucky and the seat of Franklin County.  It is a home rule-class city in Kentucky; the population was 25
column2: 527 at the 2010 census. Located along the Kentucky River
column3: Frankfort is the principal city of the Frankfort
column5: which includes all of Franklin and Anderson counties.

column1: The town of Frankfort likely received its name from an event that took place in the 1780s. Native Americans attacked a group of early European-American pioneers from Bryan Station
column2: who were making salt at a ford in the Kentucky River. Pioneer Stephen Frank was killed
column3: and the settlers thereafter called the crossing "Frank's Ford". This name was later elided to Frankfort.In 1786
column4: James Wilkinson purchased the 260-acre (110 ha) tract of land on the north side of the Kentucky River
column5: which developed as downtown Frankfort. He was an early promoter of Frankfort as the state capital.

column1: After Kentucky became the 15th state in 1792
column2: five commissioners from various counties were appointed
column4: to choose a location for the capital. They were John Allen and John Edwards (both from Bourbon County)
column7: and Robert Todd (from Fayette). A number of communities competed for this honor
column8: but Frankfort won.  According to early histories
column9: the offer of Andrew Holmes' log house as capitol for seven years
column16: 000 in gold helped the decision go to Frankfort.

column1: Frankfort had a United States post office by 1794
column2: with Daniel Weisiger as postmaster. On 1 October 1794
column3: Weisiger sent the first quarterly account to Washington.John Brown
column5: built a home now called Liberty Hall in Frankfort in 1796. Before Kentucky statehood
column6: he represented Virginia in the Continental Congress (1777−78) and the U.S. Congress (1789−91). While in Congress
column7: he introduced the bill granting statehood to Kentucky. After statehood
column8: he was elected by the state legislature as one of the state's U.S. Senators.In 1796
column9: the Kentucky General Assembly appropriated funds to provide a house to accommodate the governor; it was completed two years later. The Old Governor's Mansion is claimed to be the oldest official executive residence still in use in the United States. In 1829
column10: Gideon Shryock designed the Old Capitol
column12: in Greek Revival style. It served Kentucky as its capitol from 1830 to 1910. The separate settlement known as South Frankfort was annexed by the city on 3 January 1850.The Argus of Western America was published in Frankfort from 1808 until 1830.During the American Civil War
column13: the Union Army built fortifications overlooking Frankfort on what is now called Fort Hill. The Confederate Army also occupied Frankfort for a short time
column15: the only such time that Confederate forces took control of a Union capitol.

column2: Governor-elect William Goebel was assassinated in Frankfort while walking to the capitol on the way to his inauguration. Former Secretary of State Caleb Powers was later found guilty of a conspiracy to murder Goebel.Frankfort grew considerably in the 1960s. A modern addition to the State Office Building was completed in 1967. The original building was completed in the 1930s on the location of the former Kentucky State Penitentiary. Some of the stone from the old prison was used for the walls surrounding the office building. The Capitol Plaza was established in the 1960s.  It comprised the Capitol Plaza Office Tower
column3: the tallest building in the city
column4: the Capitol Plaza Hotel (formerly the Holiday Inn
column6: and the Fountain Place Shoppes. The Capital Plaza Office Tower opened in 1972 and became a visual landmark for the center of the city. By the early 2000s
column7: maintenance of the concrete structures had been neglected and the plaza had fallen into disrepair
column8: with sections of the plaza closed to pedestrian activity out of concerns for safety. In August 2008
column9: city officials recommended demolition of the Tower and redevelopment the area over a period of years. Ten years later
column10: the demolition of the office tower was completed on Sunday
column13: and was televised by WKYT-TV on The CW Lexington as well as streamed live on Facebook. Demolition of the nearby convention center
column14: which opened in 1971 and has hosted sporting events
column17: was completed in Spring 2018.City officials intend to replace the outdated office tower with a smaller
column18: four- or five-story building in order to create a more pedestrian-oriented scale at the complex
column19: to encourage street activity.Frankfort is home to several distilleries including the Buffalo Trace Distillery (Kentucky Bourbon)
column21: and Three Boys Farm Distillery (bourbon and whisky).Although there was some rapid economic and population growth in the 1960s
column22: both tapered off in the 1980s and have remained fairly stable since that time.In 2018
column23: several teachers protested at the city in response to Senate Bill 151 having been passed on 29 March 2018.

column1: Frankfort is located in the (inner) Bluegrass region of Central Kentucky.  The city is bisected by the Kentucky River
column2: which makes an s-turn as it passes through the center of town. The river valley widens at this point
column3: which creates four distinct parts of town. The valley within the city limits contains Downtown and South Frankfort districts
column4: which lie opposite one another on the river. A small neighborhood with its own distinct identity
column6: is located on the west bank of the river to the north of Benson Creek
column7: opposite the river from the "downtown" district. The suburban areas on either side of the valley are respectively referred to as the "West Side" and "East Side" (or "West Frankfort" and "East Frankfort").

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 14.6 square miles (37.8 km2)
column3: of which 14.3 square miles (37.0 km2) is land and 0.3 square miles (0.78 km2) is water.

column1: Frankfort does not have a commercial airport and travelers fly into Blue Grass Airport in Lexington
column2: Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport near Covington or Louisville International Airport in Louisville.  Capital City Airport serves general and military aviation.

column1: Frankfort has a humid subtropical climate with four distinct seasons. Winter is generally cool with some snowfall. Spring and fall are both mild and relatively warm
column2: with ample precipitation and thunderstorm activity. Summers are hot and humid.

column1: Frankfort is the focal point of a micropolitan statistical area consisting of Frankfort and Franklin County as well as adjacent Lawrenceburg and Anderson County.  The city is also classified in a combined statistical area with Lexington and Richmond to the east.
Frankfort's municipal population makes it the fourth smallest capital city in the United States.
Lakeview (operated jointly with Franklin County)—ball fields
Leslie Morris Park on Fort Hill—American Civil War battlefield
